@phet the configuration key for DEFAULT_ is a global fallback, if the key isn't configured

@phet Yes I can have a setting to also configure the timeunit in that case, that would make sense.
This is for configuring the default (the flows themselves are allowed to overwrite this value) so we need to perform conversion for all flows in the ctor of the DagManagerThread
Can you point me to the code where DagManager checks if the "current attempt number" is less than the "max allowed attempt number" ? Does it fetch the currentAttempt from the job status store?

> Can you point me to the code where DagManager checks if the "current attempt number" is less than the "max allowed attempt number" ? Does it fetch the currentAttempt from the job status store?

https://github.com/apache/gobblin/blob/master/gobblin-service/src/main/java/org/apache/gobblin/service/modules/orchestration/DagManager.java#L741 It fetch job status from state store and only check shouldRetry to determine whether retry is needed. we reset retry to false only in event emitted by gobblin service, but if event in service arrives later than cluster's event, then this will not be updated

I worked on this issue before https://github.com/apache/gobblin/pull/3314 closed without merge because the approach of merging was not accepted.
The base condition why this issue will appear is that events should arrive out of order. With some internal fixes that made sure that all the GTEs for a flow are sent to the same kafka partition, I made sure that events arrive in order. So this issue should not appear.

Even if somehow events do not arrive in order, there is a timestamp field in GTEs which KafkaJobStatusMonitor can use to determine which is the newer value of any property to persist in the job status store. I worked on that also, but did not send a PR because the issue could not be reproduced after the internal fix that made sure that events are sent to the same partition.

Might be outside of the scope of the PR, but would it make sense to also use skipped jobs for the following usecases?
1. When the job scheduler rejects a job due to concurrent executions in GaaS, if concurrent executions are disabled
2. If there is an internal issue in GaaS that prevents the job from being executed, such as reaching quota.

I like the semantics of adding a skipped execution status for when jobs are not actually running or doing work due to some external issue (resource or otherwise)

For those scenario, I'm not sure whether we want to do that as in those case, we haven't submitted a job from GaaS point of view and thus we will not have flow status entry created for those execution. But adding skipped status will add flow status to mysql and thus when user call API to get the latest flow status or when we want to check whether latest flow is running to submit new job, it might return a skip status and make the logic complicated.

Have we thought about the resume use case? If the last submitted job is skipped, will "resume" resume the last completed job or the skipped job. Both can have different compiled configs. Sorry, if that has been already discussed. Ignore in that case.

> Have we thought about the resume use case? If the last submitted job is skipped, will "resume" resume the last completed job or the skipped job. Both can have different compiled configs. Sorry, if that has been already discussed. Ignore in that case.

I check the code for resume case that we specify the flow execution id to be resumed. In this case, regardless the status of the skipped flow, we should be able to specify which flow is resumed? Not sure if I'm missing anything here though

I like the idea of marking in some way the 'executions' that even gaas does not proceed with.  I'd probably lean toward overloading the 'skipped' status for the uses you list @Will-Lo , but I haven't though all the implications to be certain.  what I sense is that they all have something in common: a transient condition whereby the system refuses to proceed.

while it does have implications for which flow executions get status, that seems warranted--basically not to think from the GaaS point of view but from the GaaS *user's* PoV.  the user has submitted a flow to execute and GaaS agrees to do so asynchronously.  therefore the user may expect to return later seeking the outcome of that asynchronous promise.  even now GaaS gives a status of CANCELED; here we merely wish to discern a difference.  AFAICT, skipped is a status we would want to resume, especially as the conditions for skipping all seem transient.  good idea to discuss explicitly @arjun4084346 .  being potentially more recent than a prior COMPLETE status, the skipped execution may have updated config, reflecting the user's up-to-date plan, so we should use that.

as we discuss further, my only question is whether the name 'DEFERRED' or 'STAYED' or 'REFUSED' might better capture what's the system has chosen to do than does 'SKIPPED'.

Ah actually missed that comment. 
Sometimes the flowgraph has old names of data node. e.g. LinkedIn's internal flowgraph has name griduse, but the correct name used by Azkaban was gridmem1e. Both actually mean the same node. But if we change the node, it will break old customer's code, if we add a duplicate node, it will be a tech debt to slowly deprecate the old name. I made a client side change, where it would change the name, but @Will-Lo  suggested that it would be better if we make changes on server side, because change here will be applicable to all kinds of clients and deployment will be a less step process.
@ZihanLi58 please review

in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GOBBLIN-1631 : We want one metric per thread so we can tell which thread is dead/alive. 

On what cases the thread would be considered dead ? lets say if one thread processing and encounter exception, is that considered as dead in this case? if so, what other use cases can a thread be dead ? 

also, do you think it be helpful to add additional instrument metrics such as Dags in / out  throughput to know if Dags is processing everything without backlog

> in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GOBBLIN-1631 : We want one metric per thread so we can tell which thread is dead/alive.
> 
> On what cases the thread would be considered dead ? lets say if one thread processing and encounter exception, is that considered as dead in this case? if so, what other use cases can a thread be dead ?
> 
> also, do you think it be helpful to add additional instrument metrics such as Dags in / out throughput to know if Dags is processing everything without backlog

1. If the dag manager thread always hit some exception during processing or if the thread itself never get resources to run and cannot hit the cleanDag stage for a long time, we consider it as dead.  From monitoring side, if the heartbeat metric is 0 for a  time, we can consider it as dead.
2. Yes, we can also add that if needed, just add one guage to report the total size of the dag queues should be enough for you to monitor if there is any backlog, but kind of out the scope of this PR.

> nice work!
> 
> this seemed an important element (from your PR summary):
> 
> ```
> Additionally, we also do not want to retry if a flow is skipped due to concurrent jobs running at the same time
> ```
> 
> yet I'm having trouble finding anything related to this in the impl. (a comment saying the same at the least...). does it just come down to some `CANCELED` ones not bearing a `isFlowSlaKilled.equals(true)`?

In this scenario I'm describing the timing event emitted is JOB_SKIPPED_TIME, which is emitted from the Orchestrator. Since the dag isn't created I believe a retry would be overriding the check, which is done in the DagManager (which comes after Orchestration). Also it's unlikely that the concurrent flow actually finished by the time the retry is processed anyways, since we do not have waits before retries.

Functionally speaking it's just a cancellation event which isn't user initiated that doesn't have the flag that it was killed due to exceeding the start/runtime SLA
@vikrambohra  can you help take a look when you have chance?

> Functionally speaking it's just a cancellation event which isn't user initiated that doesn't have the flag that it was killed due to exceeding the start/runtime SLA

would it be worth adding a comment when preparing that internal cancellation saying that it won't be retried because it's missing the flag?

per our conversation recently about 'semantic naming', we could always consider naming that flag something like:
```
-  public static final String IS_FLOW_SLA_KILLED = "isFlowSlaKilled";
+ public static final String DOES_CANCELED_FLOW_MERIT_RETRY = "doesCanceledFlowMeritRetry";
```
